awd_titl_txt: Engaging the Next Generation of Biochemists
awd_abstract_narration:
The field of biochemistry provides a critical foundation for students as they pursue careers in diverse fields, such as health care, and basic and applied research. To master core biochemical concepts, students must integrate background knowledge in biology, chemistry, physics, and mathematics as they learn about the dynamic structures and processes that constitute biochemical systems. Students often struggle with mechanistic reasoning, as evidenced by their inability to connect structures to functions and to properly attribute causality within decentralized systems. Hence, the ability to properly visualize and model biochemical systems represents an important means to advance student learning. Unfortunately, the traditional biochemistry classroom provides limited opportunities for students to engage with concepts in realistic and interactive ways, as primarily static, two-dimensional images and diagrams are used as teaching tools within passive, lecture-based environments. This project will transform biochemistry instruction by developing a series of easily-incorporated modules that make use of dynamic physical and computational models. These modules will focus on helping students develop their understandings of the direct relationships between macromolecular structure and function as well as the dynamic coordination of metabolic systems. At a larger level, this project will help establish new paradigms in biochemistry teaching and learning, and significantly enhance the training of the next generation of STEM professionals.

The goals of this project are: (i) to develop dynamic, structural three-dimensional (3D) models and implement these into modules for biochemistry courses to improve understanding about the complex 3D structures critical to life; (ii) to develop computational models of metabolic networks and implement these into modules for biochemistry courses to improve understanding of biochemical systems concepts; and (iii) to determine the impact of the physical and computational modules on student learning of key learning objectives. The 3D models will be developed using the cost-accessible 3D printing technology and the computational models will be built on an open-source software platform called Cell Collective, developed by one of the project's co-PIs. This platform provides a unique interactive environment for students to explore the relationships and dynamics of complex systems in ways that are not available in other simulations, and resembling authentic science practice as articulated by Vision and Change. These modules and their associated materials will be made available on-line, and dissemination efforts, including a workshop, will help propagate their use at many institutions.

por.por_cntn:
The field of biochemistry helps society address numerous threats to humanity, including water and food availability, emerging diseases and long-standing health concerns, and climate change. However, learning biochemistry can be challenging, and numerous students have difficulties with some of the key concepts needed to understand biochemistry. The goals of this project were to develop and implement novel strategies to enhance student learning of two discreet concepts in biochemistry: (i) the direct relationship between structure and function and (ii) dynamic coordination of metabolism. This project led to significantly enhanced learning of both of these concepts by roughly 1000 students in large and small enrollment classes at two institutions. Moreover, through five workshops at regional and national meetings, like one at the American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB) annual meeting, participants from across the country were guided to use and implement these resources in their classrooms. In addition, results from this project were communicated at five scientific meetings and disseminated in five publications, two of which are focused on hands-on instructions to help instructors design and use the strategies in their classrooms. Moreover, these strategies are now being exported to enhance learning in high school classrooms and have been adopted by three instructors outside the research group here at UNL. Hence, biochemistry learning of students across the country will continue to be enhanced by this project.

The approach we took for concept (i) was to develop six three-dimensional (3D) model sets targeting common misconceptions about structure-function relationships. The models were 3D printed from pliable materials such that twisting and shifting common in actual DNA, RNA, and proteins, could be mimicked, and changes in specific chemical bonds that hold biomolecules together could be simulated by the incorporation of magnets representing these bonds. The design strategies and specific details of the models for printing can be found in Howell et al. 2018 (doi: 10.1128/jmbe.v19i3.1663) and at https://www.rostonlab.com/3d-models-for-biochemistry. To maximize learning by students handling these models we designed learning activities (i.e., modules) encompassing a web-based guide of instructions and questions with immediate feedback incorporated. These learning modules proved valuable learning tools in both small and large student enrollment biochemistry courses, with student learning gains significantly higher in module versus non-module courses. The results have been published in Howell et al. 2019 BAMBED (doi: 10.1002/bmb.21234) and Howell et al. 2020. Biochem Mol Biol Educ (doi: 10.1002/bmb.21362). Our most common question from instructors interested in incorporating the models was if there was a computer-based version of the models. We made, incorporated, and tested a web-based 3D model that could be manipulated in any browser using a touch screen. These were paired with the same interactive activities. Results showed that broadly similar gains were made by the students, albeit less quickly. This may be the best option for low-income schools. A manuscript describing the success of the virtual 3D models is in progress. 

The second general biochemistry concept we targeted was the dynamic coordination of metabolism. Metabolism is complex and dynamic. As such, students often only acquire a surface-level understanding of metabolism and lack a deep understanding of the nuances of regulation and interdependence of different biochemical pathways. The approach we took to target this learning deficit was to use a computational modeling approach powered by a comprehensive and highly accessible software platform: Cell Collective (https://learn.cellcollective.org). Similar to the 3D model activities, the computer model simulations were designed with an interactive activity to guide students through a process of working with the models. We found that biochemistry students using the modules performed better on metabolism questions compared with students who did not use the modules. Moreover, we also confirmed that the modules did not create or reinforce a gender bias. The results have been published in Booth et al. 2021 LSE (doi: 10.1187/cbe.20-05-0105) and Booth et al. 2021 CourseSource (doi: 10.24918/cs.2021.39).

Besides impacting biochemistry learning of students, this project has provided training of two postdoctoral associates who now both have faculty positions. Moreover, this projected contributed to the successful promotion of three of the involved faculty to associate professors with tenure and one to full professor. In addition, this project provided an opportunity to train six undergraduate students in biochemistry education research. Finally, this project provided the seed for the design and implementation of similar types of learning modules for high school students, thus broadening the project?s impact beyond biochemistry learning by college students.
